Idiom (Norfuk): Yu no ken put pig in a dress an’ call um lady.
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Fixed clause; declarative proverb; metaphorical comparison.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: No matter how much you disguise something, its true nature doesn’t change.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent (Plain, Neutral: You can’t change someone’s nature by changing their appearance.
Usage Contexts: Daily speech, humor, moral lesson, family advice.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Rooted in rural Norfolk humor; reflects agricultural and island imagery.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Norfuk): [juː noʊ kɛn pʊt pɪɡ ɪn ə drɛs ən kɔːl əm ˈleɪdi]
First Example Sentence: Ai told hem, yu no ken put pig in a dress an’ call um lady, yu know.
Second Example Sentence: Dem try make dat ol’ boat look flash, but yu no ken put pig in a dress an’ call um lady.
Third Example Sentence: Ai laef when ai si dem house paint pink – yu no ken put pig in a dress an’ call um lady!

Idiom (Norfuk): Wan han’ can’t clap by itself.
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Proverbial sentence; negative construction with metaphor.
Figurative Meaning (Contextualized Defin: Cooperation is needed; one person alone cannot achieve everything.
Usage Contexts: Community work, family life, leadership, education.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Common across the Pacific; emphasizes community spirit central to Norfolk culture.
First Example Sentence: Yu see, wan han’ can’t clap by itself, we all mus’ help.
Second Example Sentence: Dem project no work cause wan han’ can’t clap by itself.
Third Example Sentence: On dis island, we larn early dat wan han’ can’t clap by itself.

Idiom (Norfuk): Dem tide no wait f’ no man.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Derived from maritime life on Norfolk Island; reflects seafaring wisdom.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Norfuk): [dem taid noʊ weɪt fɔː noʊ mæn]
First Example Sentence: Ai told dem hurry up, dem tide no wait f’ no man.
Second Example Sentence: Life gwen fast; dem tide no wait f’ no man.
Third Example Sentence: Yu betta go now, cause dem tide no wait f’ no man.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: You can’t stop time or delay the inevitable.
Figurative Meaning: Time waits for no one; things move on regardless of us.

Idiom (Norfuk): Ef yu plant taro, yu can’t expect banana.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Agricultural metaphor reflecting island subsistence and wisdom.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Norfuk): [ɛf ju plɑːnt ˈtaroʊ ju kɑːnt ɪkspɛkt bəˈnænə]
First Example Sentence: Ef yu plant taro, yu can’t expect banana, yu mus’ wok hard.
Second Example Sentence: Dem boy lazy; ef yu plant taro, yu can’t expect banana.
Third Example Sentence: Ai tell hem, ef yu plant taro, yu can’t expect banana, dat’s tru life.
Figurative Meaning: You reap what you sow; actions lead to matching consequences.

Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Colonial maritime influence adapted in Norfuk speech.
First Example Sentence: Ai tell dem, slowly slowly catchee monkey, no need rush.
Second Example Sentence: Yu gwen learn Norfuk fine – slowly slowly catchee monkey.
Third Example Sentence: He finish da job nice, slowly slowly catchee monkey style.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: Take your time; steady work wins.

Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Reflects seafaring culture and missed voyages.
First Example Sentence: Ai bin wan’ apply, but dem boat done sail now.
Second Example Sentence: Yu shud told mi earlier, dem boat done sail.
Third Example Sentence: Ai laugh – he still waitin’, but dem boat done sail.

Idiom (Norfuk): Wha’ gwen, no can stop, eh!
Syntactic Structure & Grammatical Form: Elliptical clause with negation; colloquial interjection.
First Example Sentence: Dem storm come fast, wha’ gwen, no can stop, eh!
Second Example Sentence: Ai told dem, wha’ gwen, no can stop, eh, jus’ let it be.
Third Example Sentence: Dem plan fall apart, but wha’ gwen, no can stop, eh!
Figurative Meaning: What’s happening can’t be stopped; acceptance of reality.

Idiom (Norfuk): Dem no ken see forest for tree.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Adaptation of English proverb to Norfuk speech rhythm.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Norfuk): [dem noʊ kɛn si fɒrɛst fɔː triː]
First Example Sentence: Ai told dem, dem no ken see forest for tree, all small thing worry dem.
Second Example Sentence: Dem manager no ken see forest for tree, ai swear.
Third Example Sentence: Wi larn dis at school, dem no ken see forest for tree.
Figurative Meaning: Someone is too focused on details to see the bigger picture.

Idiom (Norfuk): Yu ken tek horse t’ watah but no mek um drink.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Old English saying preserved in Norfolk Island dialect.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Norfuk): [ju kɛn tɛk hɔːs tə ˈwɒtə bʌt noʊ mɛk əm drɪŋk]
First Example Sentence: Ai told mi son, yu ken tek horse t’ watah but no mek um drink.
Second Example Sentence: Dem teacher laugh, yu ken tek horse t’ watah but no mek um drink.
Third Example Sentence: Ai try help hem, but yu ken tek horse t’ watah but no mek um drink.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: You can’t make someone do what they don’t want to.
Figurative Meaning: You can guide someone but not force them to act.

Idiom (Norfuk): Dem crab walk crooked but still reach sea.
Cultural Origin or Historical Reference: Local imagery; inspired by Norfolk’s crabs moving toward the sea.
Phonetic Transcription (IPA, Norfuk): [dem kræb wɔːk krʊkɪd bʌt stɪl riːtʃ siː]
First Example Sentence: Ai like dat saying, dem crab walk crooked but still reach sea.
Second Example Sentence: He do ting his own way, dem crab walk crooked but still reach sea.
Third Example Sentence: Yu tink he slow, but dem crab walk crooked but still reach sea.
Non-Idiomatic Equivalent: There’s more than one way to succeed.
Figurative Meaning: People may take different paths but still reach their goals.
